response.answer_text: Murder is karmic. It has a cause, it has an effect, it has the person committing the act stuck between the causes that led them to that point and the effects that propagate out from it. The point of dharma is to free yourself, so that the causes that lead you to a point like that do not necessarily result in the effects that propagate forward from it. One does not have to commit murder regardless of the context, or to commit oneself to the myriad consequences that naturally follow from committing murder. Karma is not bad or good. It’s like the tide; it pushes you this way or that way. If it happens to smash you against the rocks, that’s not because it’s bad or good; if it tosses you into a position where you are contemplating murder, not because it’s bad or good. You didn’t swim with the tide or against it or across it, so karma swept you where it would, and you ended up where you are. There’s nothing wrong with that or right with that. Dharma means learning to swim. I highly recommend it.

In my tradition our ethical tenet: ‘The Witches Wiccan Rede’ states: ‘An it Harm None, Less in Defense or The Greater Good, Do As Ye Will!’ To kill another person, unless in Defense or The Greater Good, will result in negative Karma! While ‘Instant Karma’ imacts the person in this life, ‘Karma’ affects the person in the next life. You see, if in the defense of a child, the attacker is killed, there would be no negative Karma at all. Please try to understand, Karma is neither Good nor Bad. It is simply a natural process intended to teach people, by way of positive and negative reinforcement, the way to live an ethical life in harmony within our communities. Blessed Be! Storm )O(
